intro: Carlina graeca, commonly known as the Greek crownflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountains of Greece and Turkey. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its striking blue to violet composite flowers. The plant has hairy, gray-green leaves that are often covered in fine, white pubescence. Carlina graeca typically grows in rocky or dry habitats, thriving in well-drained soils. Its flowers bloom in late summer to early autumn, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
